NaÌƒo ensine mulheres a prevenir serem estupradas, ensine os homens a naÌƒo estuprar." Vamos ensinar! E saÌƒo um atestado inconfundiÌvel de que o corpo se encontra sexualmente maduro â€” servindo, portanto, para atrair o sexo oposto (ou naÌƒo). E se a pessoa toma banho todos os dias naÌƒo tem porque achar pelos anti-higieÌ‚nicos, saÌƒo taÌƒo limpos quanto cabelo e barba, que ningueÌm considera anti-higieÌ‚nicos. As pessoas querem culpar a viÌtima por isso dar algum tipo de conforto pra quem escuta a histoÌria do abuso, como se ela tivesse controle sobre as violeÌ‚ncias que pode sofrer. FalaÌcia eÌ um raciociÌnio que parece loÌgico mas eÌ enganoso. Usando essa crencÌ§a, a pessoa acha que se â€œfor boaâ€, e â€œtomar cuidadoâ€, estaraÌ sempre imune a sofrer abusos. O que naÌƒo eÌ verdade, jaÌ que qualquer pessoa pode sofrer violeÌ‚ncia: pessoas boas e pessoas ruins, e as que â€œtomam cuidadoâ€ e as que naÌƒo tomam, ateÌ porque eÌ comum a violeÌ‚ncia vir de pessoas conhecidas, em quem confiamos. Por isso temos que responsabilizar agressores e prevenir que pessoas se tornem abusadores, ensinando sobre consentimento e combatendo a cultura de estupro. Cultura de estupro eÌ justificar, legitimar, relativizar, banalizar, glamurizar, ou mesmo que sem intencÌ§aÌƒo, levar a violeÌ‚ncia sexual. ALERTA DE VIOLENCIA SIMBOÌLICA EN EL FESTIVAL El Festival de VinÌƒa nos ha traiÌdo risas y emociones pero tambieÌn una ola de violencia simboÌlica que nos recuerda crudamente parte importante de la cultura en la que estamos inmersos. Â¿CoÌmo nos condiciona que un asesor de imagen, comente en TV abierta respecto a la dieta y restriccioÌn alimenticia para entrar en un vestido, pasando por alto el impacto que estos dichos tienen en el concepto de autoimagen, belleza y salud?Â¿CoÌmo podemos hablar de consentimiento y conductas abusivas cuando se normaliza que un notero pueda besar sin consentimiento a su entrevistada y esto sea avalado mediante la risa por algunos de quienes conducen el programa? En un entorno festivo, estos mensajes pueden parecer inofensivos, pero no lo son. La suma de estas conductas sucedidas en #vinÌƒa2023, normalizan acciones violentas y contribuyen a perpetuar la violencia de geÌnero. Justamente de eso se trata la violencia simboÌlica; de aquello que nos cuesta ver, que se produce y reproduce en entornos amigables y cotidianos, en espacios culturales y en medios masivos de comunicacioÌn. Son mensajes que se incorporan de manera inconsciente y por eso creemos necesario visualizarlos y conversar abiertamente en torno a ello.

La mutilacioÌn genital femenina es una praÌctica que surge desde AÌfrica y se expande hasta AmeÌrica del Sur. Puede realizarse en cualquier momento de la vida de la mujer, sin embargo, es maÌs comuÌn en la ninÌƒez. Se lleva a cabo por motivos culturales, religiosos y esteÌticos, entre otros. En algunos casos se trata de un rito de iniciacioÌn que es requisito para el matrimonio; en otros se considera un rito de transicioÌn a la madurez o tambieÌn una forma de controlar la sexualidad de la mujer y salvaguardar la virginidad de las mujeres antes del matrimonio; y por uÌltimo, en algunas comunidades existe la creencia de que garantiza el futuro matrimonio de las ninÌƒas y el honor de las familias. AdemaÌs de las graves consecuencias fiÌsicas (como hemorragias, periÌodos irregulares o infecciones) que tiene este procedimiento que no tiene justificacioÌn meÌdica, tambieÌn conlleva profundos danÌƒos psicoloÌgicos en las afectadas. La mutilacioÌn genital femenina ha sido considerada como una manifestacioÌn extrema de desprecio al cuerpo de la mujer y a lo que eÌste representa, negando asiÌ la sexualidad a las mujeres y sometiendolas a una violacioÌn de sus derechos humanos. El objetivo de este diÌa es generar conciencia sobre la existencia de esta praÌctica violenta y discriminatoria.

Nadie nace odiando su cuerpo. Nadie nace pensando que menos kilos = maÌs eÌxito, maÌs valiosa y mejor. Las expectativas son diferentes para ambos, e histoÌricamente las presiones de la belleza y el cuerpo han sido exacerbadas en las mujeres. Los TCA no son padecidos exclusivamente por mujeres, pero siÌ son la mayoriÌa. Si bien son trastornos mentales multifactoriales, el vivir en una sociedad que lucra con la inseguridad de nuestros cuerpos, que nos presiona por perder kilos, donde se nos presenta la delgadez como la uÌnica manera de ser felices y exitosas, se hace un factor precipitante o que nos hace maÌs vulnerables a padecerlos. Nuestras ninÌƒas y mujeres crecen viendo modelos y estereotipos presentados como â€œidealesâ€ que se alejan muchiÌsimo de lo que es real. Se les presentan unos cuerpos como maÌs valiosos que otros, y mientras maÌs alejados esteÌn sus cuerpos de este â€œmodelo hegemoÌnicoâ€, maÌs insatisfaccioÌn corporal existe. La cultura de las dietas se sustenta en este modelo de belleza, donde no nos venden salud, sino delgadez para alcanzar la felicidad. El bombardeo que recibimos es a toda hora y por todas partes. Sin ir maÌs lejos, en nuestras propias investigaciones hemos encontrado que el 90% de las mujeres cree que la imagen fiÌsica afecta la satisfaccioÌn con la vida, y que las mujeres pasan en promedio 3 horas al diÌa pensando en su cuerpo. Nadie nace poniendo tanta importancia en el cuerpo. Lo aprendemos a traveÌs de la sociedad, de la gente que nos rodea, la publicidad y medios a los que nos vemos expuestas. Y es por todo esto que en los TCA se hace muy evidente la necesidad de un tratamiento con perspectiva de geÌnero. No podemos siquiera pensar en un tratamiento que no tiene esta perspectiva y que no considere el factor social y poliÌtico en la vida de las mujeres. La lucha sigue hasta que los medios tomen responsabilidad, hasta que normalicemos todos los tipos de cuerpo, hasta que dejen de lucrar con la inseguridad de ninÌƒas y mujeres. Â¡Porque nos queremos libres de estereotipos y presiones!

Â¿CuaÌl es la diferencia de la terapia feminista y una terapia sin perspectiva de geÌnero? La necesidad de una perspectiva de geÌnero viene dada tambieÌn por evitar seguir perpetuando mensajes de la sociedad que son sexistas, machistas y arbitrarios, que presionan socialmente a las mujeres para cumplir con ciertas "normas" y nos encasillan en ciertos roles que nos limitan el universo de posibilades, generan estereotipos errados, una historia uÌnica y privatizan el dolor. Cuando escuchamos a personajes como @pablodiazc_ diciendo que para que nos vuelva el deseo hay que "hacer menos aseo, banÌƒarse, encremarse y ponerse bonita", es no haber entendido nada. Otros consejos del tipo "La clave no es tener los mismos gustos a ellos, es tener energiÌa masculina como ellos y asiÌ te dejan de ver como un pedazo de carne", es negar que como mujeres somos suficientes y una vez maÌs se nos responsabiliza a nosotras por ser objetificadas. Es negar TODO el danÌƒo que nos hace la sociedad patriarcal y que no tiene que ver con nuestra energiÌa, tiene que ver con la violencia estructural hacia la mujer que nos desvaloriza tal y como somos. Este tipo de psicologiÌa LIGHT no solo no ayuda, sino perpetuÌa estereotipos de geÌnero, privatiza el dolor y nos hace responsables, de nuevo, de todo lo que nos pasa, negando la influencia de la sociedad. Llevamos siglos luchando por dejar de ser cosificadas y sexualizadas y cuando hay "profesionales de la salud mental" que promueven este tipo de cosas nos preocupa y nos parece GRAVE porque perpetuÌa estereotipos machistas y patriarcales que solo presionan a la mujer, la desvalorizan y la convierten en, literalmente, un pedazo de carne.

Los oriÌgenes del DiÌa Internacional de la EliminacioÌn de la Violencia hacia las Mujeres se remontan a 1981, cuando militantes y activistas en favor del derecho de la mujer lanzaban sus protestas ante la violencia de geÌnero. El origen: la necesidad de honrar la memoria de las hermanas Mirabal, tres activistas poliÌticas de la RepuÌblica Dominicana que fueron brutalmente asesinadas en 1960 por orden del gobernante dominicano, Rafael Trujillo (1930-1961). AdemaÌs, a septiembre de este anÌƒo @onumujeres reveloÌ que a nivel mundial 243 millones de mujeres entre los 15 y 49 anÌƒos ha sido objeto de violencia sexual y/o fiÌsica por parte de su pareja en los uÌltimos 12 meses. La OMS indicoÌ este anÌƒo que, a nivel mundial, 1 de cada 3 mujeres ha experimentado violencia fiÌsica y/o sexual por parte de su pareja o por parte de cualquier perpetrador a lo largo de su vida. AdemaÌs, desde la OMS comentan que estos casos incrementan en contextos de emergencia, incluida las pandemias. Es por esto que este anÌƒo maÌs que nunca se hace importante visibilizar que las mujeres sufrimos violencia de todo tipo por el solo hecho de ser mujeres y que esta violencia se sustenta en una estructura social patriarcal que posiciona a las mujeres como seres inferiores, que socializa a hombres y mujeres de manera diferente, donde las expectativas de control sobre las mujeres son legitimadas y donde el machismo diario tambieÌn estaÌ legitimado. Todos estos factores son el caldo de cultivo para la violencia contra las mujeres. Por eso el cambio debe ser social y poliÌtico, un cambio en las estructuras maÌs profundas de nuestra sociedad que estaÌn impregnadas de machismo y desigualdad. Culturalmente se nos inculca un uÌnico tipo de amor: el amor romaÌntico. Este modelo nos dice coÌmo tenemos que querer, coÌmo tenemos que sentirnos, coÌmo tenemos que comportarnos y, por ende, cuaÌles son las expectativas que tenemos que tener de coÌmo deberiÌan querernos tambieÌn. El amor romaÌntico pone el amor de pareja en el primer lugar de la jerarquiÌa, planteando la idea de la media mitad. La dependencia emocional se viste de romanticismo para decirnos que estamos incompletas si no tenemos una pareja y que no conoceremos la verdadera felicidad hasta que la encontremos. El amor romaÌntico es monoÌgamo, solo podemos y debemos querer a una persona. Y esa persona debe solamente querernos de vuelta. Conductas posesivas aparecen como demostraciones de amor, los celos y el aduenÌƒarse de la otra persona son formas de â€œmostrar que realmente te importaâ€. El amor romaÌntico es maÌgico y ocurre en un instante. El amor a primera vista se nos vende como una senÌƒal de amor verdadero, en vez de como una idealizacioÌn de otra persona basada simplemente en las expectativas que le proyectamos. El amor romaÌntico es para siempre. No importa si implica pasarte a llevar a ti misma, porque el amor debe ser incondicional. Todas estas creencias han sido perpetuadas por nuestra cultura y la muÌsica es un reflejo de eso. Por eso hoy las invitamos a mirar criÌticamente las canciones de amor, Â¿queÌ cambios le hariÌan al amor que nos venden las canciones? Toma una captura a una letra de cancioÌn que consideres que perpetuÌe el amor romaÌntico, corriÌgela y etiqueÌtanos para que hoy juntas construyamos otras formas de amar ğŸ’œ (puedes ocupar la cancioÌn que quieras, desliza para encontrar unos ejemplos). #14febrero #diadelamor

En el anÌƒo 2019 realizamos la encuesta â€œAmor y relaciones de parejaâ€ con el objetivo de conocer las creencias y expectativas que existen en torno al amor y a las relaciones de pareja. Para ello, convocamos por redes sociales para responder la encuesta de manera online, en la que participaron un total de 2881 mujeres mayores de 14 anÌƒos, y cuyos resultados podemos ver en este post. QueriÌamos saber coÌmo impacta en nosotras lo que por generaciones se ha ido construyendo en relacioÌn al amor y a coÌmo ser pareja en una relacioÌn amorosa: desde las canciones que escuchamos, los dibujos animados que vimos mientras creciÌamos, las telenovelas y peliÌculas, donde abundan frases que romantizan la idea del sufrimiento y devocioÌn como la ceÌlebre "El amor todo lo puede y todo lo soporta", la cual peligrosamente puede llevarnos a situaciones de dependencia emocional que implica soportar algunos tipos de violencia, ya que se normalizan conductas danÌƒinas desde y hacia la pareja. Por ello, es necesario develar los â€œmitos del amor romaÌnticoâ€, los cuales se sustentan en una ideologiÌa patriarcal que subordina a las mujeres a un rol pasivo, donde se nos muestra como personas que esperan a un otro que nos â€œcompleteâ€, nos entregue proteccioÌn a cambio de abnegacioÌn o que debemos soportar todo a cambio de no estar solas. Asimismo, normalizan los celos como muestra de amor, cuando en realidad no es maÌs que control y posesioÌn sobre otra persona, lo que consolida la idea de que amor y maltrato son compatibles. Hoy, en la previa del #14DeFebrero, cuando mundialmente se celebra el â€œdiÌa de los enamoradosâ€, queremos compartir estos resultados para desprivatizar las experiencias y empezar a deconstruir las ensenÌƒanzas que el patriarcado ha dejado en nosotras, para empezar a conocernos mejor, querernos mejor, querer a un otre mejor y por sobre todo, saber coÌmo un otre debe quererme mejor. Este tipo de violencia intenta expulsar o mantener fuera a las mujeres de espacios de toma de decisiones para restaurar y sostener un orden patriarcal regresivo. Se debe quitar todo piso y tribuna a proyectos de derecha y sectores conservadores que levantan tales grados de misoginia y violencia, sin medias tintas. Y extendemos nuestro compromiso irrestricto con la erradicacioÌn de todas las formas de violencia y apoyo a todas las mujeres que cotidianamente sufren violencia poliÌtica. La Violencia PoliÌtica por razoÌn de geÌnero contra una mujer, es un ejercicio de violencia contra todas nosotras.

Hace unos diÌas les preguntamos coÌmo ha sido la relacioÌn que han tenido con sus figuras paternas y nos llenoÌ de emocioÌn ver la cantidad de respuestas diversas y sinceras que todas nos mandaron. La brecha salarial es violencia simboÌlica y violencia econoÌmica Claudia Goldin, docente e investigadora ganadora del Premio Nobel de EconomiÌa, es una precursora en el anaÌlisis de la brecha salarial de geÌnero. Fue una de las fundadoras de la AsociacioÌn Nacional para el Progreso de las Personas de Color y parte del movimiento sufragista estadounidense. Ida B. Wells dedicoÌ su vida a la defensa de los derechos civiles y de la mujer. AdemaÌs se encargoÌ de documentar cientos de casos de linchamientos raciales, lo cual le valioÌ un reconocimiento poÌstumo en la entrega de los premios Pulitzer de este anÌƒo. En 1880 Wells se trasladoÌ a Memphis y ahiÌ adquirioÌ conocimiento puÌblico tras liderar una campanÌƒa en contra de la segregacioÌn racial en el ferrocarril, luego de que fuera forzada a ceder su asiento a un hombre blanco. ContratoÌ un abogado para demandar a la companÌƒiÌa de ferrocarril y ganoÌ el caso en el tribunal local, pero luego la companÌƒiÌa apeloÌ en la Corte Suprema de Tennessee y la sentencia fue anulada. Luego, durante unas manifestaciones a favor del voto femenino se negoÌ a marchar maÌs atraÌs por ser de color. En 1889 empezoÌ a ser copropietaria y redactora de Free Speech, un perioÌdico en contra de la segregacioÌn. En 1892 publicoÌ un artiÌculo denunciando el linchamiento de tres amigos empresarios afrodescendientes por parte de su competencia. Wells entonces trasladoÌ su residencia a Chicago. ContinuoÌ publicando panfletos que daban cuenta de su investigaciones acerca de miles de linchamientos a personas por razones raciales. Luego de jubilarse Wells escribioÌ su autobiografiÌa titulada Cruzada por la justicia. En 2020, se le otorgoÌ una mencioÌn especial poÌstuma de los Premios Pulitzer por ser una pionera del periodismo de investigacioÌn y un iÌcono de la lucha por los derechos civiles. #idabwells #mujeresbacanas #blacklivesmatter

Niki de Saint Phalle fue una artista, cineasta y escultora franco-americana reconocida como una de las grandes pintoras del siglo XX, por su caraÌcter rupturista y feminista. Niki formoÌ un arte transgresor y reivindicativo que buscaba romper con las imposiciones sociales impuestas al geÌnero femenino. Fue asiÌ como realizoÌ creaciones caracterizadas por esculturas femeninas voluptuosas y coloridas con las que ocupoÌ el espacio puÌblico. Su serie de figuras llamadas â€œLas Nanasâ€ lograron un gran renombre, destacando principalmente â€œEllaâ€, una de las esculturas maÌs grandes de su tiempo y a la que se debiÌa ingresar por la entrepierna para poder apreciar el interior. De Saint Phalle destacoÌ no soÌlo por su trabajo bajo la perspectiva feminista, sino que tambieÌn por su constante defensa hacia los derechos civiles de la poblacioÌn negra y la multiculturalidad presente en la sociedad. Sus uÌltimos 20 anÌƒos de carrera los dedicoÌ para desarrollar â€œEl jardiÌn del Tarotâ€ una de sus maÌs importantes obras que cuenta con esculturas de maÌs de 15 metros de altura en las que plasmoÌ todo su estilo creativo. #mujeresbacanas #nikidesaintphalle

La estadounidense/alemana Shere Hite, pionera de la investigacioÌn sobre la sexualidad femenina, fue la primera en hacerle estas preguntas a las mujeres. RenuncioÌ a su ciudadaniÌa estadounidense y se nacionalizoÌ alemana; el resto de su vida la vivioÌ en el viejo continente. #sharehite #mujeresbacanas

La abogada tanzana Rebeca Gyumi fundoÌ Msichana Initiative, ONG que tiene como objetivo empoderar a las ninÌƒas de su paiÌs a traveÌs de la educacioÌn para que aspiren a ser maÌs que esposas y madres. La praÌctica de casarlas de pequenÌƒas es legal en maÌs de 90 paiÌses, lo que las vuelve maÌs vulnerables a sufrir violencia, pobreza y falta de educacioÌn. En su infancia vio coÌmo algunas de sus companÌƒeras dejaban la escuela al casarse y embarazarse. A los 20 anÌƒos se dio cuenta que esta era una realidad nacional. RecieÌn supo sobre la Ley de Matrimonio de 1971 cuando ingresoÌ a la universidad a estudiar derecho. En 2016, luego de ejercer como abogada algunos anÌƒos, Rebeca junto a sus colegas decidieron presentar una peticioÌn contra la Ley de matrimonio. Recopilaron informes para demostrar que el matrimonio infantil para las ninÌƒas era un problema en todo el paiÌs y por queÌ debiÌa detenerse. DesafioÌ el sistema legal en su paiÌs Tanzania y ganoÌ un falloÌ histoÌrico: elevar la edad para contraer matrimonio a 18 anÌƒos. A pesar de recibir algunas criÌticas por socavar las creencias culturales y religiosas, la mayoriÌa de sus connacionales apoyaron su lucha para acabar con el matrimonio infantil. El Tribunal Superior de Tanzania dictaminoÌ que el matrimonio de menores de edad era inconstitucional, aunque el anÌƒo pasado un grupo apeloÌ. Dijeron que el matrimonio infantil protegiÌa a las ninÌƒas de quedar embarazadas antes de casarse. Fue nombrada Mujer del anÌƒo 2016 por la revista New Africa. Anna Jarvis es quien instauroÌ la celebracioÌn del diÌa de la madre como tradicioÌn. En la medida en que la celebracioÌn del diÌa de la madre se fue masificando y tomando una connotacioÌn cada vez maÌs comercial, sobre todo para los vendedores de flores y tarjetas, a Jarvis le empezoÌ a molestar y comenzoÌ entonces una campanÌƒa para boicotear esta celebracioÌn que estaba desviaÌndose de la intencioÌn inicial. Incluso Jarvis llegoÌ a ser arrestada por realizar protestas â€œruidosasâ€ contra las floreriÌas, que aumentaban sus precios en mayo y amenazoÌ ademaÌs con demandar a muchas empresas que lucraban con la celebracioÌn. TambieÌn se pronuncioÌ contra las tarjetas que veniÌan con textos pre-impresos: â€œUna tarjeta impresa no significa maÌs que se es demasiado indolente para escribirle de punÌƒo y letra a la mujer que ha hecho por uno maÌs que nadie en el mundoâ€. Ella y su hermana Ellsinore, usaron su herencia para hacer campanÌƒa en contra de las celebraciones comerciales del diÌa de la madre. "Jarvis consideraba que el DiÌa de la Madre era su 'propiedad intelectual y legal', y no parte del dominio puÌblico", asegura la escritora Katharine Lane Antolini.

Aunque fue criticada y ofendida por su colectivo, su madre la apoyoÌ. Era la primera persona de China Cadenas en terminar el colegio e ingresar a la educacioÌn superior. Ni siquiera dominaba completamente el espanÌƒol. IngresoÌ a IngenieriÌa Forestal en la universidad privada de PeteÌn. Fundaeco la acompanÌƒoÌ en el proceso para gestionar su beca y su permanencia en la regioÌn. Pese a la situacioÌn judicial vivida, la relacioÌn con sus parientes no se quebroÌ. Es la mejor de la institucioÌn en MatemaÌticas, FiÌsica, y aspira a convertirse en protectora de la naturaleza; ayudar a otras ninÌƒas para que no tengan que dejar el colegio por falta de recursos. #mujeresbacanas

La notoria ausencia de las mujeres en China. Las mujeres representan a la mitad de la poblacioÌn china, pero brillan por su ausencia en las altas esferas del poder. El domingo se anuncioÌ la nueva cuÌpula del Partido Comunista de China (PCC) y por primera vez en los uÌltimos 25 anÌƒos ninguna mujer formaraÌ parte del PolitburoÌ integrado ahora por 24 hombres. Sun Chunlan, de 72 anÌƒos, era la uÌnica mujer en la anterior noÌmina. Conocida como la â€œDama de Hierro por su rol de inspeccioÌn sanitaria durante la pandemia, Chunlan se jubiloÌ y ninguna otra representante femenina fue designada en su lugar. El Partido Comunista ha dirigido China durante 70 anÌƒos, y en ese tiempo ninguna mujer ha sido miembro del ComiteÌ Permanente del PolitburoÌ de China, el pequenÌƒo grupo de siete personas que dirige el paiÌs. Por otra parte, en el nuevo ComiteÌ Central, parlamento del partido con 205 miembros, queda con 11 mujeres, un 4,9% del total. Y cabe recordar que las mujeres representan el 48,8% de la poblacioÌn china, y el 29,4% de los miembros del Partido Comunista. Los criÌticos afirman que en China las mujeres estaÌn consideradas como parte de la fuerza productiva y tambieÌn como madres, esposas y trabajadoras, pero no participan de cargos de poder poliÌtico, y el gobierno del presidente Xi Jinping estariÌa pronunciando auÌn maÌs ese sesgo machista. China ha implementado un sistema de cuotas desde 2001 que exige la presencia de al menos una mujer en los distintos niveles de gobierno y del partido. Pero debido a la falta de control, este sistema no es realmente respetado. Desde 1948, el PolitburoÌ del PCC soÌlo ha admitido a ocho mujeres.

Kim Hak-soon fue la primera mujer coreana en dar puÌblicamente su testimonio sobre los horrores que sufrioÌ mientras era una â€œmujer de solazâ€, una esclava sexual. Luego regresaron a Corea; a los 15 anÌƒos la adoptoÌ otra familia y la inscribioÌ en una escuela de â€œkisaengâ€ donde le ensenÌƒaban a las mujeres canto, baile y poesiÌa para que entretuvieran a hombres coreanos de clase alta. Tras graduarse su padre adoptivo la llevoÌ a China. Poco despueÌs los soldados japoneses la detuvieron y llevaron a una unidad militar. Cuando intentoÌ resistirse o huir la maltrataron. Meses despueÌs, un diÌa en que los soldados no estaban, escapoÌ. Tras la rendicioÌn de JapoÌn en 1945 se instaloÌ en SeuÌl. Tuvo una hija y un hijo que murieron joÌvenes. Su marido tambieÌn murioÌ durante la Guerra de Corea. Kim empezoÌ a hacer campanÌƒas para que el gobierno japoneÌs asumiera su responsabilidad legal y compensara a las viÌctimas. A partir del anÌƒo siguiente de su declaracioÌn, todos los mieÌrcoles se lleva a cabo una protesta frente a la embajada japonesa en SeuÌl. La periodista japonesa Shiori Ito se transformoÌ en un siÌmbolo de la violencia sexual contra las mujeres al hacer puÌblico el caso de su violacioÌn en 2017. #ArchivoBacanas Fue viÌctima de una violacioÌn. Lo denuncioÌ a las autoridades y fue a los servicios de salud. Pero Amanda Nguyen, graduada de Harvard, empleada del Departamento de Estado en Washington y con miras a ser astronauta, se dio cuenta entonces que las viÌctimas como ella no estaban protegidas; de hecho, eran obligadas a navegar por un sistema deficiente, que las haciÌa revivir su ataque y sin consideraciones, explicaciones o defensa de su lado. CreoÌ una ONG llamada Rise, que se preocupa de ayudar a las viÌctimas de violacioÌn a encausar sus acciones civiles ante la Justicia. Y convencioÌ a legisladores del Congreso de crear una nueva Ley, que entregue derechos y proteja a quienes han pasado por un crimen sexual. La Ley de Derechos para los sobrevivientes de asaltos sexuales fue firmada por Obama el anÌƒo 2016. Amanda Nguyen fue violada, y acudioÌ a la policiÌa. En su estado de Massachusetts se podiÌa esperar 15 anÌƒos para perseguir una demanda o acusacioÌn, pero los servicios de salud soÌlo guardaban el kit de violacioÌn, con la evidencia y muestras tomadas del crimen, por seis meses; tambieÌn se dio cuenta que dos veces al anÌƒo, el sistema le recordariÌa la fecha de su violacioÌn, y que debiÌa pedir proÌrrogas para no destruir el material. â€œLa parte maÌs difiÌcil fue darme cuenta que el sistema hecho para proteger y entregar justicia estaba roto. Desde poliÌticas insoÌlitas, a no entregar informacioÌn sobre procedimientos confusos, estaÌ todo en contra de los sobrevivientes. Yo quise cambiar esoâ€. AsiÌ nacioÌ Rise, con profesionales de todo tipo, con sobrevivientes y voluntarios, que se movieron raÌpidamente para cambiar las leyes; en dos meses, ya estaban llegando al Congreso. Y asiÌ nacioÌ este proyecto en donde se juntaron varias legislaciones de distintos estados para crear una ley que protegiera y apoyara a las viÌctimas. Exige que tengan acceso a ayuda sicoloÌgica especializada, y que reciban toda la informacioÌn y ayuda legal que requieran. Y asiÌ, hoy son derechos para los sobrevivientes, incluso si no han reportado el crimen a las autoridades. #amandanguyen #mujeresbacanas

Esta semana las mujeres iraniÌes se han manifestado en distintas ciudades de su paiÌs tras la muerte de Mahsa Amini, una joven de 22 anÌƒos que murioÌ la semana pasada cuando se encontraba bajo custodia de la â€œpoliciÌa moralâ€ (Gasht-e Ershad) de IraÌn, agentes encubiertos que velan por el correcto uso de la vestimenta seguÌn el coÌdigo religioso de la zona. #CitasMujeresBacanas Las hermanas BronteÌˆ eran algo ariscas y alejadas de lo que se esperaba de las mujeres victorianas de la eÌpoca, que era baÌsicamente casarse y dedicarse a las labores domeÌsticas. Eran solteras a las que les interesaba maÌs que nada leer y escribir (aunque cada una vivioÌ sus amores que quedaron plasmados en sus novelas semibiograÌficas). Como hijas de pastor no teniÌan dote que ofrecer y tampoco eran particularmente agraciadas para conseguir un marido. La otra alternativa era estudiar pero como no podiÌan costearlo, se dedicaron a la ensenÌƒanza trabajando como profesoras e institutrices. Con necesidades econoÌmicas que resolver, las hermanas decidieron publicar sus escritos para ver si lograban juntar algo de dinero. Escribieron un poemario en conjunto pero lo hicieron usando seudoÌnimos masculinos; firmaron como Currer, Ellis y Acton Bell. AsiÌ se evitaban los prejuicios machistas propios de la eÌpoca. Les fue bien en criÌticas pero mal en ventas, entonces decidieron publicar novelas por separado pero manteniendo sus identidades masculinas. A lo largo de 1846, las tres hermanas se dedicaron a escribir; Charlotte creoÌ â€œJane Eyreâ€; Emily, â€œCumbres Borrascosasâ€, y Anne, â€œAgnes Greyâ€.

Luego viajoÌ a Egipto para seguir estudiando y obtuvo los tiÌtulos necesarios para trabajar como especialista en ginecologiÌa y partera. AgnoÌdice regresoÌ a Atenas. La declararon inocente de los cargos que se le imputaban, pero fue condenada a muerte porque estaba prohibido que siendo mujer se desempenÌƒara como meÌdica. Este hecho ademaÌs de lograr evitar la pena, hizo que las mujeres ganaran su derecho a formarse y trabajar como parteras o matronas. #mujeresbacana

Brisa Stempelet es una mujer emprendedora de la regioÌn de La AraucaniÌa que se ha abierto camino en el masculinizado mundo de la mecaÌnica. La honestidad es un valor fundamental en mi taller, y siempre trato de establecer una relacioÌn de confianza con mis clientes. Es importante que ellos confiÌen en miÌ y en mi trabajo.â€ Brisa ha trabajado arduamente para formar un espacio donde maÌs mujeres puedan unirse a su pasioÌn por la mecaÌnica. Su visioÌn es convertir su taller en el primero en la comuna y la regioÌn, donde mujeres talentosas trabajen en maquinaria pesada. Brisa ha contado con el apoyo de programas como Balloon Latam, en el que recibioÌ un reconocimiento en activos que le permitioÌ arrendar el taller, ademaÌs de vincularse con DERCO Maquinaria, gracias a quienes ha podido ampliar su conocimiento a traveÌs de capacitaciones y establecer contactos con otros emprendedores. âœğŸ»Esta biografiÌa fue realizada en colaboracioÌn con @mcfundacion #mujeresbacanaschilenas #mujeresemprendedoras #emprendimientosocial #chile

Premio Nacional de Derechos Humanos del INDH 2022, la activista peruana Elizabeth Andrade Huaringa es la primera migrante en recibir este galardoÌn. Â¿CuaÌl es el rol de IA en materia de geÌnero? ğŸ¤” ğŸ¤– Gestionar las nuevas tecnologiÌas acorde a nuestra realidad actual es crucial para aprovechar su uso y crear nuevas oportunidades sin promover sesgos, estereotipos y desigualdades, maÌs auÌn cuando la IA posee un aprendizaje basado en la experiencia, dando posibilidades de repetir patrones histoÌricos. (LoÌpez. C, 2024, El Mostrador). Desde ahiÌ se plantea el desafiÌo de generar espacios libres de discriminaciones y en los que prime la representacioÌn del geÌnero femenino: soÌlo un 22% de los trabajadores en esta tecnologiÌa son mujeres y, si se analiza una data internacional de 133 sistemas, estos presentan hasta un 44,2% de sesgos de geÌnero (El Mercurio, 2023). No obstante, si utilizamos la IA en pro de la equidad esta herramienta es muy uÌtil para procesar grandes datos y algoritmos, logrando identificar sesgos de geÌnero y agilizando procesos para buscar la igualdad (Forbes Chile, 2023). La ciencia tambieÌn es de mujeresğŸ—£ï¸ Â¿SabiÌas que solo el 30% de las personas investigadoras en ciencias son mujeres? Con 9 deÌcadas de historia, solo 8 mujeres han sido nominadas a mejor director en los Oscars: Lina WertmuÌˆller (1975), Jane Campion (1993 y 2022), Sofia Coppola (2003), Kathryn Bigelow (2009), Greta Gerwig (2017), Emerald Fennell (2021), ChloeÌ Zhao (2021) y Justine Triet (2024). Justine Triet y la edicioÌn 2024âœ¨ â€œAnatomiÌa de una caiÌdaâ€ es un filme que centra su historia en la sospechosa muerte de un hombre que cae desde la ventana de su hogar en los Alpes franceses. AdemaÌs, en la edicioÌn nuÌmero 49 de los CeÌsar, Justine y su filme se llevaron los principales premios (direccioÌn y mejor peliÌcula o mejor guion original). Directora y guionista de cine francesa, Triet posee un trabajo cinematograÌfico que ha explorado la complejidad de las relaciones humanas, las luchas sociales y de las mujeres, mezclando elementos de comedia, drama y thrillers. La francesa es tambieÌn parte del colectivo 50/50 que centra sus esfuerzos en plasmar la paridad en el cine. â€œEl cine debe contribuir a la revolucioÌn social feminista (...) Hoy tengo claro que necesitamos historias hechas por mujeres, dirigidas por mujeres, juzgadas por mujeres. TodaviÌa estamos muy lejos de la paridadâ€, recalcoÌ en el diario El PaiÌs. #mujeresbacanas #oscars2024

Homofobia y bifobia. La homofobia, es el acto de rechazo, repudio, prejuicio o discriminacioÌn hacia mujeres y hombres que les gusta su mismo genero. SeguÌn AmnistiÌa Internacional, maÌs de setenta paiÌses persiguen a los homosexuales y ocho hasta los condenan a muerte. La palabra homofobia fue utilizada por primera vez por el psicoÌlogo estadounidense George Weinberg en 1971. AnÌƒos atraÌs, Wainwright Churchill se habiÌa referido a la homoerotofobia. Otro concepto relacionado es el heterosexismo o heterocentrismo, el cual permite darle nombre a la creencia de que los heterosexuales son, por naturaleza, organismos superiores en relacioÌn a los homo y a los bisexuales. Por otro lado, la bifobia es el odio, rechazo, repudio, prejuicio o discriminacioÌn hacia las personas que les atraen ambos sexos. Al igual que la homofobia y otros tipos de discriminacioÌn hacia la comunidad LGBT+. aquellas personas que rechazan, discriminan la diversidad sexual de mujeres, hombres o binaries. En cuanto a la fobia bisexual, se cree que estas personas estaÌn pasando por fases entre hetero-homo. Esa creencia tambieÌn es discriminacioÌn ya que cancela la atraccioÌn de las/e bisexuales e incitando a creer que no existe. Que nadie te diga a quien debes amar

Denuncia por violencia intrafamiliar. Las denuncias se pueden realizar en los Juzgados de Familia, Carabineros, la PoliciÌa de Investigaciones o el Ministerio PuÌblico. Si no existe evidencia de violencia fiÌsica, o la denuncia es por violencia psicoloÌgica o econoÌmica, el mejor camino es el Juzgado de Familia. En el caso de que exista constatacioÌn de lesiones, se puede denunciar en el Tribunal de familia o directamente en las FiscaliÌas del Ministerio PuÌblico. Â¿Es necesario contar con pruebas o documentos para denunciar? NO. Para realizar la denuncia basta con el testimonio de la afectada. Â¿QuieÌn puede realizar la denuncia? La afectada o cualquier persona que conozca los hechos. TambieÌn tienen derecho a solicitar que su identidad se mantenga en secreto. Â¿Puedes denunciar violencia intrafamiliar si no estaÌs casada o no vives con el agresor?SIÌ. La ley de Violencia Intrafamiliar (VIF) contempla denuncias en contra del marido o ex marido, del conviviente o ex conviviente, incluyendo a pololos o ex pololos, siempre que existan hijos/as en comuÌn. Â¿QueÌ tipo de medidas de proteccioÌn puede dictar el juez o jueza? Si bien es el o la jueza quien determina queÌ medida de proteccioÌn va a dictar, tuÌ puedes sugerirle aquellas con las que te sentiriÌas maÌs segura y protegida. Por ejemplo: Ingresarte a una casa de acogida. Prohibir al agresor que se acerque a ti. Ordenar el reintegro al hogar de quien injustificadamente haya sido obligado/a a abandonarlo. Prohibir a quien ejerce la violencia acercarse al establecimiento educacional donde asisten sus hijos/as. Prohibir al agresor portar armas de fuego. Solicitar a Carabineros rondas perioÌdicas a tu domicilio. Realizar mejoras en tu hogar, como por ejemplo cambio de chapas o protecciones en las ventanas para hacer de tu hogar un lugar maÌs seguro. Hacerte entrega de un celular, en caso de no contar con uno o que quieras que tu nuÌmero sea privado para que puedas solicitar ayuda. InformacioÌn. Gracias por leer. Te invito a seguirme

El geÌnero condiciona nuestra existencia. No nos cansaremos de senÌƒalarlo. IlustracioÌn de una servidora con maravilloso texto de @carmenhijosconexito: ğŸŸ¡Sexo no es geÌnero La semana pasada, compartiÌ un post en el que explicaba las diferencias entre â€˜sexoâ€™ y â€˜geÌneroâ€™. Parece ser que auÌn no estaÌ muy claro, porque en algunos casos, seguiÌs utilizaÌndolos como sinoÌnimos y en otros, me deciÌs que no lo entendeÌis muy bien. Puntualizo algunos conceptos del artiÌculo de mi blog. Enlace en bio e historias. Mirad este otro dibujo que ha preparado @tessaimpresa, refleja a la perfeccioÌn el significado de cada idea. Millones de gracias por tu trabajo. El sexo es una caracteriÌstica bioloÌgica que se transmite geneÌticamente, marcando las diferencias fiÌsicas. Hay dos sexos: hombres (machos) y mujeres (hembras). El sexo es inmutable. Se puede observar, por ej, entre las piernas. Se tiene vulva o pene. SeguÌn estos genitales externos, desde el nacimiento, la mayoriÌa de ninÌƒas son criadas para ser complacientes, sumisas, deÌbiles, sensibles, emocionales y para que se dediquen a las tareas domeÌsticas y los cuidados de las personas. Y la mayoriÌa de ninÌƒos, seraÌn criados para que tengan un rol dominante, se responsabilicen del dinero que entra en el hogar, seguros de siÌ mismos y no exterioricen las emociones, etc. A esto se le llama geÌnero. Es, por tanto, un constructo social. Es algo que aprendemos. Dicta coÌmo deben ser y comportarse los hombres (masculinidad) y las mujeres (feminidad). El geÌnero (no el sexo) es lo que crea las desigualdades sociales. No hay nada en nuestros genitales (sexo) que haga a las mujeres inferiores a los hombres. El sexo (la vulva y la vagina) por siÌ mismo no explica las desigualdades que sufrimos las mujeres. Sin embargo, es el motivo por el q las sufrimos. La biologiÌa (menstruacioÌn, menopausia, las molestias derivadas de estas, dolores del parto, los amamantamientos, crianza, cuidados) ha limitado enormemente a la mujer y es la causa de q estemos subordinadas al hombre. Pero el ser humano no es solo animal, es maÌs cosas. De ahiÌ, la necesidad de que esta opresioÌn acabe. Si queremos eliminar la violencia de geÌnero (estructural), que no la violencia intrafamiliar, tenemos q educar en igualdad a ninÌƒas y ninÌƒos #sexonoesgeÌnero

Thereâ€™s a view that women have less value as they age, while older men become more attractive. At the same time, men like to convince themselves that they are much more worthy as they age, so of course it is totally fine and not creepy when they are 50 years old hitting on women in their 20s. Happy Women's History Month! Throughout history, women's discoveries, inventions and contributions have been underplayed or omitted entirely by the men who stole their credit as well as the men who wrote the history books. When you consider the barriers and oppression these women had to overcome to gain the education, resources, time and access to the equipment needed for these discoveries, these omissions are even more egregious. The idea of one man revolutionising history through his special genius is a false narrative, created by men who wish to paint themselves that way. The story of discoveries and intervention is more often than not one of teams, teams building on the work of people that have gone before them, teams that include women, and benefit from the labour and work of women. Also sometimes men just straight steal the work of women, they get away with it because the structural power is on their side. So let's give these incredible women to long overdue credit they deserve. (Even if we can't give them the Nobels they deserve) Source: The independent, Scoopwhoop, Feminism4everyone #herstory #womenshistory #historylovers #internationalwomensday #womeninhistory #iwd2023 #internationalwomensday2023 #womensupportingwomenâ¤ï¸ #womensday #iwd #womensmonth #womenshistorymonth #womeninstem #womeninstemfields #intersectionalfeminism #internationalwomensday #intersectionalfeminist #womenshistorymonth #feministquotes #feminist #feminism #femaleempowerment #womeninleadership #womenshistorymonth #womensrights #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #empoweringwomen #feministaf #womensupportingwomenâ¤ï¸ #socialjusticeeducation #womenshistorymonth2023 #historylovers #womenshistorymonth #girlpowerğŸ’ª #historymeme

When I was growing up, I felt excluded from skateparks and football pitches and traditionally â€œmaleâ€ outdoor areas. When my friends and I went to the skatepark, we were told to leave on multiple occasions by boys. After a while we just stopped showing up. A recent study by The Royal Institute of British Architects highlighted research that found 80 per cent of the people who use outdoor spaces and equipment for young people are male. Academics from the Department of Educational Studies at Goldsmiths university, gave evidence to the inquiry & said girls are not given the access to community spaces that boys are. And added that they feel they do not have a â€œrightâ€ to use skate parks, while often equipment is built with the â€œdefault male userâ€ in mind, so the height of equipment is often set too high. Iâ€™m learning how to skate in my late 20â€™s, and even I find this is still the case. Iâ€™m trying to reclaim some of those spaces, and have been learning to skate for about a year and a half now. While things are definitely changing for the better, it seems they are not changing quickly enough. Public space, and recreational spaces should be equal and accessible to all. Itâ€™s incredibly sad that in 2024 girls STILL feel that they donâ€™t have access or are able to be in these spaces. These studies are also rarely inclusive of the experiences of gender non conforming and trans kids, who surely have an even tougher barriers to accessing these spaces. The charity Make Space for Girls is trying to address and change this, but we need more investment funding and urgency into democratising and creating spaces that arenâ€™t restricted by gender. #makespaceforwomen #makespacefortranspeople #makespaceforgirls #publicspaces #safespaces

If yesterday has highlighted anything, itâ€™s the grim reality of how dangerous male entitlement can be. The root cause of this is misogyny. Itâ€™s patriarchy. Itâ€™s sexism repackaged as â€œbeing a betterâ€ or â€œrealâ€ man, by toxic social media influencers. Itâ€™s social media companies themselves allowing this content to be eaten up, unchallenged. Itâ€™s an entire society that turns a blind eye to the cause of violence towards women and girls. None of these problems are new, they have just repeatedly been left to fester, morph and grow until we are at a place where a high profile public figure can come on live Tv and make misogynistic remarks about a woman, and the next day lament the death of a 15 year old girl by a boy - and not see how those actions are connected. Misogyny breeds violence. Itâ€™s never just a comment, banter, a joke - itâ€™s a culture that enables women to be seen as less than men. As disposable, without agency. We didnâ€™t need to have this horrific wake up call. It shouldnâ€™t take the violent death of a teenage girl for society to listen. Misogyny should be treated with the same severity as any other form of terror and violence. This isnâ€™t something women should have to put up with anymore.

"I had just started working as an administrator for a car dealership. As you can imagine, it was 90% male and lad culture was rife. The daily remarks on my appearance ranged from run of the mill "compliments" e.g. you look nice to the graphic i.e. speculating about how I would be in bed, commenting on my figure in lewd detail, in short they began to wear thin very quickly. â € One day, I was on my lunch break and stood outside in the staff car park which was in the back. I was on the phone to my boyfriend, pacing between two cars as we chatted and then I paused to rest. Out of nowhere, I felt an aggressive squeeze on my bum, I turned around and one of the drivers (who was weeks away from his retirement), just smiled and winked at me. I was so shocked that the only words I could seem to say were 'I'm on the phone to my boyfriend!'. He walked off to the garage without a word or an apology. I reported it to my line manager straight away, he told me this would get really ugly for me and advised me to let it go. His boss, who was on holiday when the incident took place, told me he had expected me to have a sense of humour about the whole thing and said 'don't be so dramatic.' I quit the next day" - Jayannaâ € Thanks to @nukketdesigner who designed the gorgeous text ğŸ’–ğŸ¨. Why are women expected to dress sexy while men aren't? Because how we understand "sexy" in our culture is all about the male gaze. In a patriarchal culture, failing to meet the male gaze, demonstrating sexual agency as a woman, and/or not conforming to a narrow set of beauty standards are all met with sexist backlash. Women's success under the patriarchy is tied to how fuckable they are. Woman can't simply opt out of this, no matter what choices individual women make about the way they dress or behave, womenâ€™s choices would still be limited by the desires of men. The way that women conduct themselves in a sexist society, even when problematic, is not worth critically analyzing without attention to the wider context of the patriarchical system we are trying to survive and thrive within. Our society values physical attractiveness, but our cultural construction of femininity places a premium on beauty and body size, as an integral aspect of what is valuable. Our society tends to be more forgiving toward men who deviate from dominant beauty standards of muscularity because there is less emphasis on the way he looks, and perhaps more so on how smart he is, how successful he is, or if he is a good 'breadwinner' for his family. "Dad bods" are seen a sign that a man is devoted to his family and his female partner. While "mom bods" are rarely truly represented in our media (though some incredible mums are using social media to change that). Mum's are pressured to 'snap back' after the physical trauma of birth and are seen as "lazy" and "unattractive" if they embrace their new body. As someone who is 5' 8" I have experienced rejection from men due to my height plenty of times, I am have in the past wished I was shorter so more men would see me as dating potential. I have never been particularly bothered by men's height myself but when I have dated men a couple of inches shorter than me, I have noticed how odd people think it is. People make all kinds of judgements about relationships and people's gender roles based on people's height. I have certainly found myself doing a Princess Di and trying to shrink myself around men who are shorter than me. My current boyfriend is the same height as me and I think it's great being able to see eye to eye with no neck straining. Height preferences in dating is so common and so normalised (especially in heterosexual relationships), and like other preferences it's worth considering where it comes from: do you feel uncomfortablely big around men who are shorter than you, like you are taking up too much space or taking on a more masculine role? Do you see taller men as being more masculine or more of a protector or more of a man? No one is forcing anyone to dating someone they don't want to, it's just always worth in life considering where your desires come from and if they are really as innate as we tend to think they are. (This is part of my "Feminist Reacts" Love Island series, for much more check out my stories and my Patreon link in the bio) #loveisland #loveislanduk #loveislandcontestants #loveislandreactions #loveislandreacts #loveislandmoments #loveisland2022 #feministaccount #loveislandmeme #dating101 #loveislandcontestants #feminist #feminism #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #datinglife #feministmemes #smashthepatriarchy #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #loveislandaftersun #intersectionalfeminism #bodiposi #bodypositivity #dating101 #datingpreference #takeupmorespace #genderoles #feminismisforeverybody #selflove #dating101 #everydaysexism #bodyimage #selfloveclub #selfworthmovement

It feels weird posting this because 32 really isn't that old, but a 28 year old went viral on TikTok with a similar video where loads of teenagers were freaking out about ageing in the comments. When you are a woman, you are either too young or too old. You are expected to hate your skin, hate any changes, and hate any sign of ageing, even though ageing is an inevitable part of life. I have so many memories of women in my life telling me how lucky I have to have young skin and tearing themselves apart ğŸ˜”. I don't want to feel that way, I want to feel neutral and be able to enjoy and live my life, free from the fear that my skin might not fit a certain ideal. Demonising ageing is one of the many ways the patriarchy keeps women in their place, the more wisdom and experience you gain, the less valuable and worthy you are. It divides women into categories and pushing them into living in fear of the passage of time. It pushes women to spend time, money, and energy agonising over their skin. Women fear ageing for good reason. Older women face economic and social discrimination. Women who don't wear makeup face economic and social consequences. Women who don't fit into the patriarchy's narrow ideals face discrimination and violence. Feeling neutral is a goal we can all hopefully aim for. #misogyny #ageism #feminism #feminist #smashthepatriarchy #feministaf #genderroles #agingdisgracefully #aging #30flirtyandthriving

One of my earliest baby feminist memories is being interrupted by my grandmother while playing and asked to go help with set up for dinner in the kitchen, when I pointed out that my older brother haven't been asked, just me and my sisters, I was told to stop being difficult. You better believe I dragged my brother into that kitchen so fast ğŸ˜„. To his credit, he also realises how unfair that was and is raising his son different. The unequal nature of domestic labour gets even more pronounced during the festive season, as so many mothers and other women take on the burden of creating the perfect Christmas with little or no support. They feel the pressure to make everyone else's time magical but they deserve support and they deserve to rest too! The only way to break this pattern is to teach boys to get off their arse and help and to refuse to pander to men perfectly capable of taking on tasks themselves. Get your own mother a present yourself ğŸ™„ #feministchristmas #genderroles #domesticlabor #genderinequality #herstory #feminism #feministnews #feministquotes #womensupportingwomenâ¤ï¸ #feminism #feminist #intersectionalfeminism #intersectionalfeminist #16daysofactivism #feministaf #raisingboys #socialjusticewarrior #raisinggirls #childraising #christmasmagic #misogyny #christmasiscoming #equality #christmasquote #christmastips #smashthepatriarchy #christmasquotes #feministaf #socialjusticeeducation #toxicmasculinity #xmasiscoming #motherhood

Many people watching this clip will think to themselves "well I would leave him if he spoke to me like that" But that is why love bombing is a key stage of the pattern of emotional abuse. Love bombing is characterised by excessive attention, admiration, and affection with the goal to make the recipient feel dependent and obligated to that person. It is a manipulative tactic. It makes you feel special, needed, loved, valuable, and worthy, which are all the components that contribute to and increase a personâ€™s self-esteem. In the Love bomber stage, everything seems perfect. You have all the validation and affirmation youâ€™ve ever wanted. But then, after the love bomber has gained your trust, the switch happens, and behaviour like this emerges. The conning, manipulation, and abuse begin. Like a switch, this person who once made you feel like so good starts to belittle, control, and devalue you. And because you had a taste of how it could be in the love bombing stage, you are more willing to give them leeway and make excuses. You think "well if I am just less annoying, he will return to the lovely man I first met." They don't return (except temporarily), it only gets worse. Victims of this behaviour will often feel very confused and mentally all over the place. This is by the perpetrator's design. It is never your fault. (This is part of my Married at First Sight series, for much more sign up at the Patreon link in the bio) -#lovebombing #marriedatfirstsight #britishtv #realitytv #smashthepatriarchy #emotionalabuse #healthyrelationships #mafs #marriedatfirstsightuk #mafsuk #redflags #redflag #feminist #feminism #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #redflagsinmen

There is typically an escalation in abusive behaviours as the abusive partner becomes comfortable with abuse, know they can push the boundaries and often as a considered response to increase or maintain control over the other person. Many people dismiss acts like punching a wall as "well I didn't hurt anyone" so it doesn't "count" or even "well I didn't hurt anyone" so it is a good action because they see it as releasing their anger without punching a person. Many people dismiss it as men just being out of control or even as a "healthy" expression of anger because "boys will be boys". If someone genuinely can't help themselves from smashing stuff when they are angry, they need anger management therapy. Punching a wall is violent and it is a huge red flag, one you should run from. Destroying your belongings shows a desire to hurt you. Domestic violence is born from small changes in already violent acts. Abusive words and threats escalate, smashing stuff escalates, pushing escalates, and punching escalates. Femicide doesn't happen out of nowhere. "Smashing things" is listed as a type of domestic violence by the National Domestic Violence Hotline for a reason. #controllingrelationships #maleviolence #redflagsindating #smashthepatriarchy #redflagsinmen #abusiverelationship #domesticabuse #redflags #redflag #feminist #feminism #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #misogyny #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #domesticabuseawareness #redflagsinmen #gaslightingawareness #controllingrelationship #toxicrelationships #healthyrelationship #domesticviolenceadvocate #feministmemes #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #emotionalabuse #gaslighting #domesticviolence #misogyny #domesticabusesupport #youdesrvebetter #relationshipadvice #boyswillbeheldaccountablefortheiractions #abusivebehaviour

In relationships, both partners should support the other to learn and grow, but too many men are entering adulthood and entering romantic relationships without the basic skills needed for successful healthy relationships. This fails men, and it fails the women who have to put in the labour, energy, and patience needed to make their relationship with this man that they love work. In times gone by, this dynamic wasn't challenged. Women were told not to expect much emotional support from their partners and to just be happy with that. After all, you didn't have much choice. But now we expect relationships full of love and connections, we deserve those relationships, and for that to be possible, the skills of emotional intelligence, communication, empathy, and listening are needed. Women who, from a young age, are expected to learn these skills, are more likely to enter into adult romantic relationships already equipped with them, men are not. But these skills are not inherent, they are can be learnt. Men are perfectly capable of learning them themselves and not putting all that emotional labour onto their current or future partners. Because love only goes so far, women won't be sticking around to grow a man anymore. We expect them to be fully grown. As someone who was in a relationship with a man 10 years senior in my early 20â€™s, much of this â€œcase for marrying an older manâ€ reads like a list of red flags.ğŸš© The 1st one that really hit home, was the describing of an other half not as a partner, but as â€œmy mentor, lover, and in only certain contexts, my friend.â€ When my relationship ended, something Iâ€™d told myself throughout was that he was more of a mentor to me than a partner. The problem with this was, with a 10 year age, earnings and work experience gap, there was a huge power imbalance. Yet one of the most obvious things in this article is the security and romance the author writes about doesnâ€™t come from an age gap, it comes from a wealth gap - which makes it read like a modern version of a 1950â€™s housewife manual for finding a â€œgood husbandâ€. Iâ€™m aware we are in the midst of a cultural pivot back to â€œtraditionalâ€ values, anti-feminism, the stay-at-home-girlfriend and tradwives. (Did these ever really leave?) & Iâ€™m not going to sit here and tell people to not marry rich or work - women should be able to do what they want. However there is a more pressing case to be made for looking out for signs of coercive, emotional and financial control. According to @survivingeconomicabuse : ğŸ”´1 in 6 women in the UK experience financial abuse in a current or former relationship. ğŸ”´95% of women who experience abuse report experiencing economic abuse. ğŸ”´More than half of women experiencing DA said they had no money so couldnâ€™t leave. This is a grim reality for countless women & worth mentioning if we are having the â€œmarrying richâ€ convo. â€œI live in an apartment whose rent he pays and that shapes the freedom with which I can ever be angry with him.â€ Iâ€™m sure there are many benefits to marrying rich- but at what cost? When the house of cards is built on youth, beauty and mentorship - what happens when we grow up, our bodies change, or we eventually want a career or financial freedom? I fear this article doesnâ€™t make a case for marrying older, it makes a case for finding financial independence and a partner who doesnâ€™t treat you like a pet...

What does it mean to be "a wife"? Women are just as capable as men of internalising patriarchal ideas about women and their role in relationships. In our society, the meaning of and history of marriage is so deeply rooted in patriarchy and gender inequality, that when these women talk about being "a wife" they imagine it as a role that serves "a husband" through domestic and sexual labour, rather than as a partnership between two equals. The patriarchy tells women that they exist to serve others, that they must prove that they can do this (by being hot, by doing unpaid domestic labour, by being good at sex, even by getting an education) in order to be 'worthy' of marriage and 'worthy' of the role of wife. Women don't exist for men. That should be pretty simple to understand, yet not for some men. Men who listen to misogynist "influencers" like this guy it isn't. One the largest Tory donors, Frank Hester made racist, violent and misogynistic comments about Labour MP Dianne Abbot in 2019. While Hester claims they were â€œrudeâ€ - he completely failed to acknowledge the extreme, hateful misogynoir in these remarks. So what exactly is misogynoir? As you might know, Misogyny is an extreme form of sexism, defined as the hatred of women. Misogynoir is a term coined by the queer Black feminist Moya Bailey in 2010, referring to a specific form of sexism - rooted in racism. The term blends concepts that combine â€œmisogynyâ€ and the French word for black, â€œnoir.â€ The concept was also notably introduced by Sojourner Truth, who spoke out about misogynoir before the term was coined in her â€œAinâ€™t I A Womanâ€ speech at the Womenâ€™s Convention in 1851 There are PLENTY of ways that misogynoir manifests in real life - and sadly, these absolutely VILE and shameful comments from Tory donor Frank Hester are an example of exactly that... Sources: Northeastern University Blackburn Centre The BBC The Telegraph

Many of you might remember that I attended a MAFS event hosted by the show where, during the Q&A, I called out Brad's behaviour and asked them why they continued to put abusers on the show (I mention George from last season too). I was shut down with "they are maybe moving too fast." We saw it for what it was. One of my aims is to make the world a lot less comfortable for abusers, while also showing that they aren't "evil monsters", they are people we know. I want to give people the tools needed to call out this behaviour, to call it unacceptable. Many people, either due to their own experiences or knowledge, are able to identify emotional abuse when they see it. That doesnâ€™t mean it is easy to escape abuse relationships or save your friends from abusive relationships or identify the abusers in your life, but it can be a tool in your arsenal. Some abusers are far more open (like Brad), others are much better at playing the "nice guy," but I want people to be able to see their friends being treat like Shona and understand the need for a girls' night where they ask her if she is OK and needs any support. To have a mate like Brad and to understand the need to tell him that you won't stand for his behaviour and explain why. People in relationships deserve basic respect. No one should think that belittling and manipulation is something that someone who loves you will do. Love bombing is a manipulative tactic designed to make the victim think later on that it will get better ("if I just change in the way he wants me to, he will love me again"). It won't get better, you deserve better, seek support to help you leave. â¤ï¸ (This is part of my Married at First Sight series, for much more sign up at the Patreon link in the bio) -#lovebombing #marriedatfirstsight #britishtv #realitytv #smashthepatriarchy #emotionalabuse #healthyrelationships #mafs #marriedatfirstsightuk #mafsuk #redflags #redflag #feminist #feminism #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #redflagsinmen

Did you know the majority of incidents of harassment on public transport happen between 5-6pm during rush hour? This is an incredibly important piece of research that has just been published by the BBC, as it completely busts the myth that harassment happens when you are alone, or travelling in the middle of the night in an empty carriage. These are the kind of myths that often perpetuate victim blaming narratives and donâ€™t lead us towards useful solutions to tackle the problem. We know that harassment can happen at any time, in any place of course , however itâ€™s imperative that we dispel these misconceptions once and for all so we can create better systems of prevention and supporting survivors. Thanks BBC News for having me and my hot take on this new piece of research around the rise in reporting incidents of sexual harassment on public transport. ğŸ™ If you are travelling, and you witness an incident. Doing something is better than nothing, we need all commuters to engage and become active bystanders to we can tackle this problem together once and for all â¤ï¸ #endharassment #sexualharassment #publictransport #bbcnews

In today's episode of #NobodyToldMe, we're joined by beauty influencer and creator and host of the podcast 'What would the auntie say?', @anchal. Anchal is a British-Indian make-up artist, who has built up a large online community through her brilliant digital make-up tutorials and honest reviews. After leaving University with a degree in special effects make-up seven years ago, she spotted, in her words, what little visibility and representation brown girls had in the online beauty world, and subsequently began producing her own content - quickly gaining traction with an audience who had previously been neglected. So far in the first series, she's covered everything from mental health and marriage to anti-blackness and colourism. She believes strongly that the only way to tackle outdated and judgemental views is for younger generations to feel they have the tools to educate and challenge the older generations. But one of the big issues she tackles is navigating life as a single woman at an age when she is expected to be married. When you love someone you know intimate details about their life, you know their trauma and their experiences, maybe better than anyone else in their life. This might mean that if they treat you in a disrespectful, hurtful and/or abusive way, you are have the excuse at the tip of your tongue: "what he did was wrong but (insert difficult life experience here)." Being a supportive, kind and empathy person doesn't mean anyone gets to disrespect you. You can support someone to heal their trauma without staying in a situation that is harmful to you. You can be understanding of what someone has been through in their life without excusing their current harmful actions. You can love someone still have boundaries and standards about how they treat you. Every adult is responsible for their own harmful actions, whatever has happened in their past. Every adult is responsible for their own healing, you can't force someone to change, no matter how much you love them. Sometimes you have to walk away and that's ok #genderbasedviolence #intersectionalfeminism #smashthepatriarchy #victimblaming #feministaf #socialjusticeeducation #socialjusticeeducation #healthyrelationship #toxicmasculinity #intersectionalfeminist #healthyrelationshipsmatter #feministquotes #notallmen #feminist #feminism #coercivecontrol #healthyrelationshipsmatter #rapeculture #misogyny #feminismisforeverybody #rapecultureisreal #domesticviolenceawareness #domesticabuseawareness #domesticabuseadvocate #genderedviolence #toxicrelationships #domesticabuse #healthyrelationshipeducation #domesticviolenceprevention #domesticabusesupport

â€œThis ad was opposite my place of work. I had to stare at it out of the window. A colleague and I went out and added the graffiti. You can see that there are two handwritings! It was a way of taking over the poster. [...] By writing angry but humorous graffiti, we were also making the point that ad agencies donâ€™t have the monopoly on wit.â€ - Jill Posener, London, 1979 ğŸš¨ğŸš— Have you ever heard of â€œculture jammingâ€? Maybe, maybe not - but you might have heard of the Guerrilla Girls - an anonymous feminist collective of women artists formed in 1980â€™s in New York, who challenged discrimination in the art world. They engaged in a practice known as culture jamming, which was a set of tactics aimed at disrupting the status quo, uprooting dominant order and turning it on its head. Jill Posener is a British feminist photographer, known for her exploration of lesbian identity, who played a key role in culture jamming in the UK, with her signature edge of wit and sarcasm. Posenerâ€™s work is one of many feminist pieces being displayed at a new exhibition at the @tate @tatebritainlondon ,â€Women In Revolt! Art and Activism in the UK 1970-1990â€, opening next week from 8th Nov 2023 â€“ 7th April 2024. If you want a re-education in feminist art or need a spot for a cute first date, this exhibition is the place for you!! ğŸ˜¤ğŸ’˜ğŸ’ª

Artemisia Gentileschi is one of the most celebrated female painter of the 17th century and she was something so rare that it seems impossible: A 17th century female artist who was able to use her art fight back against the male violence that dominated the world she lived in. To express her rage at the oppression she experienced. At 18, she was raped by her artist mentor, she publicly accused him at a time when that alone was rare. During the trial she was tortured in the court room with thumb screws. Her rapist was set free, not because he was proven innocent but because he was protected by the Pope. And so she painted her pain and painted her imagined revenge in the form of Judith Slaying Holofernes (a tale from the Old Testament). While her male contemporaries were painting adoring Madonna or a naked nymphs, her painting and her skill you can really feel. I could have looked at it all day. Yet it was in a room as just an add on to the Caravaggio collection and nothing in the giftshop carried its image. I felt like the Uffizi Gallery in Florence doesn't really value it and what it stands for as much as they should. #artemisiagentileschi #uffizigallery #femalerage #rapeculture #femaleartist #arthistory #herstory #womenshistory #historylovers #womeninhistory #womensupportingwomenâ¤ï¸ #womeninart #intersectionalfeminism #internationalwomensday #intersectionalfeminist #womenshistorymonth #feministquotes #feminist #feminism #femaleempowerment #womensrights #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #empoweringwomen #feministaf #womensupportingwomenâ¤ï¸ #historylovers #girlpowerğŸ’ª #historymeme

Yesterday was the 3 year anniversary of the day serving officer Wayne Couzens abused his police powers, abducted, raped and murdered Sarah Everard. It is hard to fathom how the horror of what happened to Sarah could get any worse, but since Lady Elish Angioliniâ€™s inquiry published last week, it appears the police had plenty of opportunities to stop Couzens from offending, yet the harrowing fact of the matter remains that they didnâ€™t, time and time again. The true magnitude of failures in vetting and policing have come to light, and it lays bare what we already knew: that the police didnâ€™t take sexual harassment seriously enough. Couzens was a repeat sex offender before he ever crossed paths with Sarah Everard, including nine indecent exposure allegations, but somehow managed to evade any consequences and kept working as a police officer. Indecent exposure or â€œflashingâ€ can sometimes be brushed off as a â€œjokeâ€, â€œnot that seriousâ€ - or just â€œsome weirdoâ€, and is rarely dealt with or acknowledged with the gravitas and seriousness it warrants. When society, authorities, people in positions of power and privilege ignore and dismiss the â€œsmall stuffâ€ - it sends a message that that kind of behaviour is okay, which allows for more serious forms of violence to escalate unchallenged. This is also known as the Pyramid of Sexual Violence, and is precisely why I have spent the past 7 years advocating around the awareness and combatting of everyday harassment and assault. When we ignore sexual harassment, that includes indecent exposure - we ignore misogyny, we ignore attitudes of sexism, we ignore women girls and marginalised genders feelings, safety and security. We also ignore a brewing problem of misogyny being left unchecked to evolve into sexual violence. The police had many opportunities to stop Couzens, but they turned a blind eye. Let this be the last time we have to remind the police that ALL forms of sexual harassment are completely unacceptable and should never ever be tolerated, and - I canâ€™t believe I even have to say this sentence - especially by actual POLICE officers. #badapple #rottentothecore #saraheverard

Many of us were lucky enough to be raised in households where we were raised to see ourselves as equal to our brothers or other boys in our lives. This is obviously important and powerful, but it gives you as a little girl a false expectation of the world. That it is one where you will be treated equally. That you will be a human being first and foremost. The dawning realision that this isn't the case no one prepares you for: when older men start treating you as a sex object, when teachers make sexist comments, when you enter the workplace and you are overlooked and belittled, when you start dating and are treated badly. It is shocking, it should be shocking. Every generation of girls has had to face this. Each generation has fought to make the world better for the next. We pass on the torch, there is still far to go. #herstory #feminism #growingupagirl #womensupportingwomenâ¤ï¸ #genderroles #raisinggirls #feminism #feminist #femaleempowermentquotes #misogyny #feministaf #beingawoman #feminism #feminist #misogyny #feministquotes #womensrights #smashthepatriarchy #feministaf #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #feministmemes #feminismquotes #feminismisforeverybody #feministquotes

One of the most eye opening things about the Jonah Hill texts has been the polarising reactions from men and women. (Not all men not all women bla bla - Iâ€™m binary for the sake of the point) These texts have triggered a mass outpouring of women sharing their stories of experiencing controlling and abusive behaviour, because thatâ€™s exactly what these texts are - controlling and coercive, masked as setting â€œboundaries.â€ But whatâ€™s depressing, has been the amount of men coming to Jonahâ€™s defence, rather than listening to the shared and lived experiences of women. Men have been saying, â€œheâ€™s setting a boundaryâ€ or â€œyou donâ€™t know what abuse isâ€ - which goes to show that ALOT of men still donâ€™t know what boundaries OR what abusive behaviour looks like. Now this gets all the more complicated with the (predominantly good) wider access and destigmatisation of men accessing therapy, which on the whole is a *great* thing. Whatâ€™s NOT so great, is the weaponisation of so called â€œtherapy speakâ€ when it gets to setting boundaries and the way we behave in romantic relationships. Let me make one thing clear: boundaries are things that you impose on yourself, they arenâ€™t things you can impose on, or control in others. Whatâ€™s also clear is the misunderstanding of how abuse and coercive control in relationships starts. It rarely starts with physical violence, but it almost always begins with limiting and controlling the other persons freedom and asserting fear and domination. This can then escalate into more controlling behaviour, and create an atmosphere of constant fear, which can and often does result in abusive and sometimes violent acts. Nearly every woman will know the feeling of walking on eggshells, or adjusting their behaviour in some way to appease a man. Whether thatâ€™s a partner, a boss, even a parent. We have been making ourselves smaller and more malleable for men for centuries, but we have also learnt that we donâ€™t deserve to be treated like objects, playthings or pets anymore. We know what the warning signs look like, and we have shouted from the top of our lungs to warn others. Itâ€™s clear that some men just still arenâ€™t listening. #jonahhill

Consent is about communication, it should be freely given and enthusiastic. Enthusiastic consent can look like this: Asking permission before you change the type or degree of sexual activity with phrases like â€œIs this OK?â€ Confirming that there is reciprocal interest before initiating any physical touch. Letting your partner know that you can stop at any time. Periodically checking in with your partner, such as asking â€œIs this still okay?â€ Providing positive feedback when youâ€™re comfortable with an activity. Explicitly agreeing to certain activities, either by saying â€œyesâ€ or another affirmative statement, like â€œIâ€™m open to trying.â€ Using physical cues to let the other person know youâ€™re comfortable taking things to the next level (Source: RAINN) (This is part of my Love Island series, for much more, including daily analysis, check out my Patreon link in the bio) #loveisland #loveislanduk #loveislandreactions #loveisland #loveisland2023 #loveislandmeme #loveislandbants #loveislandcontestants #feminist #feminism #intersectionalfeminist #feministaf #britishtv #realitytv #loveislandcast #feminismisforeverybody #smashthepatriarchy #datinglife #datingtips #dating101 #healthyrelationship #consentmatters #consentculture #consenteducation #rapeculture #consentmatters #consentissexy #consentismandatory #feminismisforeverybody #bodyautonomy #consent #intersectionalfeminism #intersectionalfeminist #feminist #feminism #realitytv

Giving children an option of a hug, high five or a fist bump gives them a choice, it empowers them and teaches them that their body autonomy and consent matters. We often talk about it content and boundaries in the context of romantic relationships situations, but itâ€™s a skill we can use in any relationship. Helping our kids learn to assert their personal boundaries and respect those of others helps to lay the foundation for creating healthy romantic and sexual relationships when theyâ€™re older. Starting consent lessons early will help kids define boundaries and express themselves in their relationships now and for the rest of their lives. Everyday is a great day to be an active bystander!! Today I want to talk about bystander intervention and share a post illustrated by @hellomynameiswednesday - based on a video from Collective Action For Safe Spaces. When we talk about bystander intervention, we often think of the most extreme version of this - something like a citizens arrest. But it doesnâ€™t have to always be that confrontational, in fact there are many ways you can show up for and advocate for a person who is being harassed. When it comes to some of these ways, you might hear people refer to the 5 Dâ€™s. Those are known as: Direct Delegate Delay Distract Document While some of the ones illustrated in this post are slightly different, the majority of the messaging is the same. However - I would like to caveat that I probably wouldnâ€™t engage or encourage the 3rd option if you are a woman or marginalised person, this is probably something in my opinion, that only a person who holds a certain amount of privilege and has done an extensive risk assessment could get away with - even then itâ€™s definitely most risky option! Iâ€™d be interested to hear others thoughts on this below. These directions are supposed to show you options for how you can engage, sometimes itâ€™s as little as asking someone if they are okay. Remember, when doing so please be safe and consider the safety of others around you. However doing something, is better than doing nothing. #bystanderintervention #activebystander

When Anna* was 33, she found out that her husband of two years was cheating on her. At first, the reason behind the breakdown of her marriage made her feel ashamed, but as divorce proceedings got underway, that shame gave way to anger. She was determined that people should know exactly what had happened. â€œI told all and sundry what type of person he is,â€ she says. â€œHe was an arse and the world should know what he did.â€â  â  Annaâ€™s unapologetically combative approach stands in stark opposition to the picture of divorce that has often been painted â€“ by celebrities and non-famous folk alike â€“ over the last decade. Throughout the 2010s and into the 2020s, there has been a pervasive social expectation that, if couples canâ€™t do til death do us part, they should at the very least end things amicably. â  â  In an age of conscious uncoupling, a messy divorce can be frowned upon but what if thereâ€™s something to be gained from releasing your rage? Do you remember when we told women to "fight sexism in the workplace with power poses"? That TED talk has thankfully had its moment, but there are still variations on this that get repeated, girlboss tips telling women to not say "just", to take ! out of their emails, to dress in a certain way, or speak a certain way. They are told to speak up and learn in! These tips claim to give women confidence and help them progess in their careers, and maybe for some individual women, they will be helpful. But, these tips are more likely to be at best useless and, at worst harmful. Research shows that women who are seen as too assertive or not assertive enough are punished in the workplace. Women have to trend a fine line between the two, an impossible task. Because women changing the behaviour can't fix an inequal system. Research shows that women are just as likely as men to ask for higher salaries, and men and women are equally likely to report avoiding negotiations if they feared it would hurt their relationship with their boss. But women are less like to get those raises when they ask. Why do we think that is? Devaluing "feminine" traits like being friendly, speaking softly, or standing in a particular way isn't helpful in the long run. Blaming women's lack of confidence or lack of assertiveness on why they aren't in leadership is victim blaming. Individual women are up against systemic inequality and misogyny. That is why there aren't enough women in leadership positions; that is why women are underpaid and overlooked. The only solution is a reimaging of power and leadership as a position for any gender and where feminine behaviours are seen as just as valuable as masculine ones, think Jacinda Ardern. Fix the system, not the women. #bossbabeğŸ‘‘ #bossbabemindset #bossbabequotes #girlbosslife #girlbossmindset #girlbosslifestyle #femalehustler #girlbossquotes #girlbossinspiration #feminismisforeverybody #powerpose #misogyny #womensmonth #womenshistorymonth #powerfulwomen #equalityintheworkplace #workplaceequality #femaleleadership
