!!ï¸ IMPORTANT!!ï¸ Sexual harassment has a *severe* impact on women and marginalised genders mental health. It causes anxiety, depression, trauma, and dictates how we make hundreds of tiny decisions throughout the entire day. It impacts *every* part of our lives, and it makes those tiny -what should be mundane - decisions feel HUGE. But when the thing causing this anxiety is your boss? Not only that, but someone you live in a close proximity too? And your complaints or concerns are being ignored? I canâ€™t imagine how destructive and isolating the impact of that would have been. The harassment Jaysley Beck endured from her army boss should not under *any* circumstances be downplayed as a factor in what happened to her. And nor should the accountability of the army - these things do not happen in a vacuum. They happen because some men can and will abuse their positions of power. They happen because of patriarchy. They happen because of misogyny going unchecked, ignored and unchallenged. They happen because they have been allowed to happen. And what about women? Well, women have been forced and socialised to make sure men donâ€™t feel rejected. To keep men happy. Not wound their fragile egos. Constantly appease and be polite as to not appear rude, for fear of repercussions. So we donâ€™t get treated aggressively. So we donâ€™t upset them. So we donâ€™t get called frigid. So we donâ€™t make a scene or cause a fuss. So we donâ€™t get killed. Because an insecure man with a wounded ego can be a very dangerous thing. Because we have been told that we are responsible for for menâ€™s feelings and actions. Itâ€™s fucking exhausting. And itâ€™s fucking unfair. Harassment ruins lives. It ruins opportunities for women and marginalised groups. It makes your world smaller. It has real life consequences, and Itâ€™s fundamentally a symptom and an aggravating factor of gender inequality. We will never be equal until we feel safe. RIP Jaysley. Sending so much support to your family and friends â¤ï¸â€ğŸ©¹ This shouldnâ€™t have happened.

Did you know almost 2/3 women have been sexually harassed at work? Well...if you follow this page, youâ€™re probably not that surprised. A new study from the Trades Union Congress has revealed that 2/3 women experience harassment, bullying or verbal abuse at work & that most victims do not report for fear of not being believed, or wanting to damage future career prospects or work relationships. Iâ€™m sorry...#MeToo has gone too far WHO? WHAT?? Just no! We have always needed more than just a hashtag or infographic to create meaningful actionable change, and make women and marginalised folk feel safer in public spaces - but these statistics are so depressing! Itâ€™s been 5 years since MeToo, and we are still living in a time where women are scared to speak out about being harassed for fear of losing their jobs. Has much progress really been made? Perhaps the awareness around MeToo has meant more people can recognise acts of harassment for what they are, but has the culture on a whole changed enough? If looking at the business sector in this country is anything to go by, the recent allegations against the CBI really say it all. I had a look into the prevalence of workplace harassment when doing my photo series #frontlineharassment - speaking to key workers during the time of the pandemic about their experiences being harassed at work. This was at a time where we were all clapping for carers & NHS workers, when at the same government was giving out pitiful pay rises. It sparked a huge conversation around workplace safety, harassment claims and how little women are appreciated in key worker roles. We know itâ€™s not just frontline workers who experience daily harassment, itâ€™s everyone else apparently too. (or as the survey points out - 62% of women age 25-34) These figures are unacceptable in a modern functioning society. Women and people of marginalised genders will never truly be equal to men if we are constantly being tormented in our place of work, alongside all the other forms of discrimination we already face. How many more years is it going to take???? #safespace #workplaceharassment #endharassment #endworkplaceabuse #endabuse #endworkplacebullying

I find it interesting when cis men talk about wanting large families, especially single men. They very rarely acknowledge that they are talking about a woman they haven't even met yet risking her life and her health to achieve this dream of his. Men who have this dream are very unlikely to take on the burden of labour of a large family after the birth either. Over the past half-century, fathers in America nearly tripled their child care time from 2.5 hours per week in 1965 to seven hours per week in 2011. But, over this period, womenâ€™s parenting time too has increased â€“ from 10 hours per week in 1965 to 14 hours per week in 2011. This pattern repeats in the UK. When considering time spent in child care plus time spent in housework and working for pay, the birth of a baby increased mothersâ€™ total workload by 21 hours per week. In contrast, fathersâ€™ total workload increased by only 12.5 hours per week. This represents a 70 percent greater increase in workload for women compared to men. These differences cannot be explained away by differences in paid work hours or breastfeeding With this in mind a man wanting a large family isn't the same as a woman wanting one. Throughout history, people, particularly women, from the upper classes would showcase their wealth through uncomfortable fashions, for example, heavy fabrics, items you need someone else to help you put on, or fashions that restrict your movement and therefore ability to work. Anything that makes it harder to work, showcases that you don't need to work, you are too wealthy for that. Especially for women, where class is a larger factor than men in how much work they were expected to perform. A lower class woman would have to earn money for the household as well as perform domestic labour, a higher class woman could have servants or slaves perform domestic labour and her restricted freedom would make her a trophy of her husbandâ€™s wealth. In modern USA, the top 20% of Americans owned 86% of the country's wealth and the bottom 80% of the population owned 14%. Americans have the highest income inequality in the rich world and over the past 20â€“30 years Americans have also experienced the greatest increase in income inequality among rich nations. On Selling Sunset, they throw around numbers like 20 million without batting an eyelid, they are part of the wealthy elite created by hypercapitalism. No wonder they act like Marie Antoinette. (I have SO MUCH more to say about Selling Sunset, which I will be sharing with my Patreon subscribers, you can enjoy the fun by subscribing at link in my bio) #capitalism #wealthinequality #sellingsunsetnetflix #sellingsunsettv #sellingsunset #sellingsunsetseason6 #realitytv #netflix #realitytvjunkie #capitalismkills #hypercapitalism #capitalismsucks #fuckcapitalism #wealthequality #fashionhistory #realitytv #inequality #taxtherich #incomeinequality

In the U.K, 64% of undergraduates in the arts are women, but 68% of the artists represented at top London commercial galleries are men? This is one of the reasons why I teamed up with Bee illustrates to set up grassroots, feminist charity exhibition that platforms women and marginalised genders using their practice to call for change called: Hysterical. Hysterical is an annual art exhibition and series of creative events celebrating the artwork of marginalised creatives, which fundraises for charity each year. After the success of our first fundraiser in 2023, Hysterical Social Club is returning bigger and better than ever with an evening of talks, workshops, art, and the opportunity to connect and network with our creative community. There will be a Q+A session with Bee Illustrates and Eliza Hatch, performances, variety of artworks, crafts and stalls, make-your-own-friendship-bracelets, and even queer match-making. Guests will receive a free goody bag - so make sure you get down early to nab yours! More exciting acts TBC! link in bio - Look forward to seeing you there <3 20th February 2024 @bprojectspace ğŸ’—ğŸ’—ğŸ’— #socialclub #hystericalsocialclub #hystericalcollective #hysterical #hystericalsocialclub #creativeevent #londoncreative #londonartscene #londoncreatives #londonart #feministsocial #social#feministcontent #feministart #feministevent

Did you know that on any given day in 2021, there were 132,000 individuals living in modern slavery in the UAE? Earlier this week I visited a new exhibition in Soho highlighting stories from women survivors of human trafficking. The exhibition provides a platform for important stories to be heard, featuring real testimonies from Nigerian, Ghanaian and Kenyan women who were misled with the promise of well paid jobs in Dubai, and instead forced into sex work. Their passports are often confiscated by their traffickers, and the women are told that to regain their travel documents and their freedom â€“ they must pay their employer huge sums. The exhibition is organised by Send Them Home, a campaign group helping to repatriate Nigerian women trafficked to the UAE - working with the Nigerian National Agency for the Prohibition of Trafficking in Persons and Hope Education Project, a pilot education programme in Ghana tackling human trafficking at its source. You can help raise awareness to #StopHumanTrafficking by: 1. Sharing this video 2. Visiting the exhibition to learn more about the survivorsâ€™ stories. Visit the exhibition until 20th December at 59 Greek St London, W1D 3DZ #AD #ProtectWomen #LondonExibition #StopHumanTrafficking Sources: WalkFree Reuters Nigerian National Agency for the Prohibition of Trafficking in Persons Hope Education Project

Is anyone else watch the news and doomscrolling in a state of despair? Or is that just me...? Every time I look at my phone things seem to be ramping up to new levels of chaos and government incompetence...and itâ€™s all starting to feel a biiiiit much. ğŸ¤¯â € Iâ€™ve seen a lot of people posting things like, â€œItâ€™s just one Christmas itâ€™s fineâ€ and â€œthings will be better next yearâ€ which is all well and good, and *hopefully* true for some people. But I also think itâ€™s important to allow yourself to have all the feelings, to sit in this moment and give yourself a break. Itâ€™s okay to feel sad right now, to feel overwhelmed, to feel let down by our government, to feel angry and conflicted about everything going on. â € Things will get better eventually, and not feel so doom and gloomy. Thatâ€™s something we can all look forward to for sure. But if youâ€™re having a hard time looking a bit further down the line, youâ€™re not alone. If youâ€™re not feeling super festive at the moment, thatâ€™s very understandable. And If you need to lie under a blanket for a few days and hide from the world, I think we all need that too. â € For anyone struggling here are some numbers for helplines: â € Samaritans: 116 123â € Mind: 0300 123 3393â € SHOUT: text 85258â € CALM: 0800 58 58 58â € PAPYRUS: 0800 068 4141â € Refuge: 0808 2000 247â €

Your not alone. I personally find this time of year tricky anyway, and can sometimes find myself falling into social media comparison holes, doubting myself or worrying that Iâ€™ve not done â€œenoughâ€. â € â € However this year, Iâ€™m not doing that. Iâ€™m aware of how eye-wateringly cheesy this all sounds, but I donâ€™t care ğŸ˜˜.â € â € Iâ€™m looking forward to next year. To whatever happens, even though there is still so much uncertainty, and at this particular moment in time, things are feeling stranger than ever. HaÌ uma grande conexaÌƒo entre o fascismo e o patriarcado Jason Stanley no seu livro "como funciona o fascismo" explica muito bem com exemplos do que aconteceu no continente africano. Em 1990, o jornal proÌ-poder hutu, Kangura, publicou os Dez Mandamentos Hutus. Os treÌ‚s primeiros relacionavam-se com geÌ‚nero. O primeiro declarava traidor qualquer um que se casasse com uma mulher tutsi, manchando, assim, a pura linhagem hutu. O terceiro preconizava que as mulheres hutus assegurassem que seus maridos, irmaÌƒos e filhos naÌƒo se casassem com mulheres tutsis. O segundo mandamento eÌ: Todo hutu deve saber que nossas filhas hutus saÌƒo mais adequadas e escrupulosas em seu papel de mulher, esposa e maÌƒe de famiÌlia. NaÌƒo saÌƒo elas bonitas, boas secretaÌrias e mais honestas? Na ideologia do poder hutu, as mulheres hutus existem somente como esposas e maÌƒes, encarregadas da sagrada responsabilidade de garantir a pureza eÌtnica hutu. Essa busca pela pureza eÌtnica foi uma justificativa baÌsica para matar os tutsis no genociÌdio de 1994.

Preciso de mim como nunca precisei Cheguei a uma fase da minha vida que aos olhos do mundo parecÌ§o naÌƒo dar valor ao que me rodeia nem ao que devia constituir preocupacÌ§aÌƒo. Estou egoiÌsta sim e tenho me amado, ligado pra mim mesma, saiÌdo sozinha pra apreciar o sol, tomado cerveja no quarto e rido dos meus tombos, tenho lido tudo e todos.
